title: government took 8 months review
story: Government took  months to review one text message linked to £m Covid dealThe Department of Health and Social Care said it had to take a law-breaking  days to perform a public interest test on whether to disclose the -word WhatsApp - nearly a week per word Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe Government took eight months to agree to publish a single text message related to a meeting between a minister, a Tory bigwig and a firm handed £m of Covid contracts. Campaigners accused the Department of Health and Social Careof witholding information for “news management purposes.”DHSC claimed it had taken a law-breaking  days to perform a ‘public interest test’ on whether to disclose the  word iMessage - nearly a week per word.The message saw a businessman tell a minister he was looking forward to a forthcoming meeting and wish him a “good night.”The message was eventually handed to the Mirror just hours after the Cabinet Office published its ‘terms of reference’ for the forthcoming public inquiry into Covid-. Tom Brake, chair of Unlock Democracy, said: “This is another example of the timing of FOI responses being used for news management purposes. “Even in the most bureaucratic of bureaucracies it is hard to see how it could take  months to review a  word text.” DHSC confirmed in July that communication records existed relating to meetings between former Health minister Lord Bethell, former Tory chair Lord Feldman and representatives of Meller Designs.It has since been revealed that Housing Secretary Michael Gove referred Meller Designs to the ‘fast lane’, while he was the minister in charge of Government Contracts.Meller Designs was handed a total of £ million worth of PPE contracts at the height of the pandemic.The firm was, until January , co-owned by David Meller, who helped to run Mr Goveaposs failed Tory leadership campaign in , has personally donated £, to Mr Gove and a total of £, to the Conservative Party. The Mirror has been pursuing the department to release records of communication between Mr Meller, Lord Bethell and Lord Feldman relating to the meeting. But officials claimed the material could be “commercially sensitive” and related to the “freedom to formulate policy”, so they needed more time to decide whether it would be possible to publish. Mr Brake said there was “not much evidence” that the text had “any bearing on ‘freedom to formulate policy’ and ‘commercial sensitivity’. The iMessage message from Mr Meller to Lord Bethell, sent at .pm on April , , saw the businessman thank him for a phone call that day, confirm the meeting the following day and wish him a good night. It read: “Hi James, Good to speak to you earlier. Appreciate your time. The guy I was speaking to at the MoD was Bruce Marshall. His number is [redacted]. I look forward to talking to you tomorrow with Andrew Feldman. Have a good night. David.Mr Marshall is a senior executive at the Ministry of Defence, and led the department’s PPE procurement project.A spokesperson for the Department of Health and Social Care said: “The department is extremely busy - with lots of FOI claims to deal with - so we can only apologise for the delay in the response.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Lord BethellTom BrakeMichael GoveLord FeldmanNHSMeller DesignsConservative PartyMinistry of DefencePublic inquiryPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: putin lost just doesnt realise
story: Vladimir Putin has lost. He just doesnt know it yetThe only issue is how the rest of the world makes it clear, says Fleet Street FoxVladimir Putin - loseropinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsCast your mind back to the last time you played Monopoly with a sore loser. He - and itaposs always a he - insists on being banker. He declares your family tradition of stashing all the fines in Free Parking to be against the rules. His pile of cash and houses seems to grow every time someone goes to get another bag of crisps, or pops to the loo.Then one player he has driven to the brink of bankruptcy lands on Free Parking, and scoops the jackpot. The balance of the game swings away from the bully. He is found in breach of the rules himself. The others co-ordinate against him, and dad - itaposs always dad - gts his cash and assets to the person most likely to destroy the aggressor. When he buys hotels no-one visits, is jailed and unable to take rent, when the lie that he was All-England Monopoly Champion  is finally disproved, and he has been reduced to being little more than a tiny, pewter boot, he flips the board in a fury.  Weaposve all played with that guy. And picked up the pieces afterwards. We all know there was never any point in helping him to lose more gently so that he could save face. He needed to lose - and for everyone to know it.The wheels have been ripped off Vladimir Putinaposs unserviced trucks. The tanks have been immobile on the roads, and have now gone off-road to become immobile in the mud. Goliathaposs planes and helicopters have been shot down by Davidaposs surface-to-air missiles, and the children Putin sent to war have died in such numbers heaposs been forced to order up mercenaries and Bashar al Assadaposs surviving conscripts. Heaposs shut down the TV stations, lost his Big Macs, and destroyed the mobile phone masts which his own intelligence forces were using to communicate. His generals are dying on the frontline because they had to abandon the control room to get their orders followed. He restructured Russiaaposs economy to be based on energy extraction and supply, and half the worldaposs stopped buying it overnight. The only people choosing to be on his side are the thicker end of the Cha terraces.Nothing in those previous two paragraphs happens when youaposre winning. Andit happens in the space of two weeks, the board-flipping moment when Putin realises his own failure cannot be far off. But whataposs worrying the West is what heaposll do to distract from the loss. Will he mine or gas Ukraine as he retreats  Will he fire tactical, smaller nukes which will obliterate buildings, irradiate the concrete dust sucked into the fireball, and then allow microscopic, inhalable radioactive particles to fall gently along the routes of prevailing winds  Perhaps he will release any one of the deadly pathogens he holds within the worldaposs largest bioweapon stockpile.Thataposs why world leaders, analysts, and journalists talk about an off-ramp, giving the madman an exit where he can make a dignied withdrawal and save face. They want him to think he can keep his job and his billionsonly he de-escalates, and steps back from the brink.The problem with that is a madman in a tank doesnapost give a s*** about the rules of the road. The point at which he was sane enough to spot and take an exit route was waaaaaaaay back, before he lost his mind. If this guy saw an off-ramp now, heaposd bomb it.If Putin is capable of using unimaginably-bad weapons - and he is - then he is adrt from the reality he would need to have any instinct of self-preservation. The flipping of the board is as certain as the coup daposetat the oligarchs he created will stage to save their looted billions. The issue with both is not , but when. Read more If it happens soon, thousands and maybe millions of lives can be saved. The Russian economy can recover, and the world can help Ukraine pick up the pieces. To act against Putin, his deposer needs to be more realistic and practical than he is, which is why it would work in the worldaposs favour and is perhaps also why it hasnapost happened yet among the men he has manipulated and paid off for two decades.Thataposs the end-game the world and its leaders must seek, because Putin is past the point of saving his own face. He would happily saw it off himself, then threaten to do everybody aposs,you let him have so much as a butter kne.The world needs him to lose. To have no exit, and to know it. All despots must see what happensyou invade a sovereign nation, and that the Westaposs immense financial power, whether in the shape of official sanctions or a spontaneous customer boycott, is a weapon with no possible defence.Because he was always going to flip the board one day,you let him play. Giving him an off-ramp means heaposs still mad, and heaposs still got a tank. Letting him slice off a piece of Ukraine is like letting him go bankrupt, but keep a hotel on Mayfair. We should never have sat down with someone who has never obeyed, but only imposed, rules. We are counting the cost of making money while he picked on someone . But the only upside of playing a game with a sore loser is that, when he loses, he feels sorest. Economically throttling his cronies is the swtest, best and only weapon we can use, because they want to keep playing this game. Our best hope is that Putin realises heaposs lost when the board, and all the lives on it, are no longer within his reach. title: uk sanctions roman abramovich six
story: Roman Abramovich and six more Russians sanctioned - travel ban and asset freeze explainedCha FC owner Roman Abramovich was named alongside billionaires Igor Sechin and Oleg Deripaska on the sanctions list over links to Vladimir Putin as the UK ramped up its response to the Ukraine-Russia warCha owner Roman Abramovich Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Cha football club owner Roman Abramovich has been sanctioned over links to Russiaaposs Vladimir Putin as the UK slapped asset freezes on seven oligarchs accused of having the blood on the Ukrainian people on their hands.The updated UK sanctions list said Mr Abramovich has had a close relationship for decades with Putin, which the football club owner has previously denied.The Russian businessman was named alongside billionaires Igor Sechin and Oleg Deripaska on the list, which imposes assets freezes, travel bans and a prohibition on transactions with UK iniduals and businesses. These elite iniduals have a collective net worth of £ billion, the Foreign Office said in an official announcement. Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said: The blood of the Ukrainian people is on their hands. Todayaposs decision brings the total number of Russian oligarchs sanctioned by Britain to , with another five already on the list. Sanctions have also been imposed on Putin, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and a number of Belarusian officials  Liz Truss said: Today’s sanctions show once again that oligarchs and kleptocrats have no place in our economy or society. With their close links to Putin they are complicit in his aggression.The blood of the Ukrainian people is on their hands. They should hang their heads in shame. Boris Johnson said: There can be no safe havens for those who have supported Putinaposs vicious assault on Ukraine. We will be ruthless in pursuing those who enable the killing of civilians, destruction of hospitals and illegal occupation of sovereign allies. Shadow Foreign Secretary David Lammy said it was the right decision but it should not have taken the Government weeks. He said: Too few oligarchs linked to Putinaposs rogue regime have so far faced sanctions from the UK Government. We are lagging far behind allies in the EU and the US.It is right that, under pressure from Labour, the Government U-turned to strengthen sanctions legislation. Ministers must now move faster to continue to close the sanctions gap.Here are the new names added to the sanctions list. Roman Abramovich Roman Abramovich is one of the most high-profile Russian oligarchs in the UK thanks to his ownership of Cha Football Club. Abramovich, who is worth an estimated £. billion and has a multi-million pound property empire in the UK, also has stakes in steel giant Evraz and Norilsk Nickel, the UK Government said. He sold a % stake in Russian oil firm Sibneft to state-owned gas titan Gazprom for £. billion in . He recently announced plans to sell the top-flight football club, which he has owned since , after initially saying he was passing stewardship to the clubaposs charitable foundation. Abramovich has denied having strong ties with Putin but the Government said he had had received financial benefits from the Kremlin, including tax breaks for his companies, the buying and selling of shares from and to the state at favourable rates, and contacts in the run up to the  World Cup in Russia.The list shows he has been sanctioned both on the basis of his personal connections to the Kremlin and preferential contracts over the years, but also the role the Evraz steel company plays - the British government believe it is providing steel to the Russian military The football club has now been seized by the UK Government but ministers have issued a licence authorising Cha to continue playing matches. Season ticket holders and those with games already booked can still attend matches, but no new tickets can be sold and the clubaposs merchandise shop will close. Abramovich’s UK property will also be frozen with not even cleaners allowed to enter it. But the asset is still only “frozen” - not actually seized by the UK government. Technically the tycoon’s family - who are not directly targeted with sanctions - could stay in his homes but officials believe it would be practically very dficult. Oleg Deripaska Industrialist Oleg Deripaska, who is Abramovichaposs former business partner, was among those newly added to the sanctions list. The Russian tycoon has stakes in En+ Group, a major extractives and energy company which owns UC Rusal, one of the world’s major aluminium producers. Deripaska is estimated to be worth £billion, with a multi-million pound property portfolio in the UK.  He hit the headlines in  when he hosted Labour grandee Lord Peter Mandelson and then-shadow chancellor George Osborne on his yacht in Corfu. Mr Osborne was accused of trying to solicit a donation for the Tory party from the oligarch - something he denies. The US designated Deripaska in , which is means a personaposs assets are blocked and U.S. persons are generally prohibited from dealing with them. Igor Sechin Tycoon Igor Sechin is the chief executive of Rosneft, the Russian state oil company. The UK Government described him as a particularly close and influential ally of Putin and he is understood to be regarded as Putinaposs number two.  He has already been sanctioned by the US and EU. The French Government seized a yacht linked to the oligarch last week. Andrey Kostin Andrey Kostin is the chairman of VTB bank, Russiaaposs second largest bank. The bank was designated by the UK last month. The UK put his net worth at an estimated £ million. Kostin was described by the FCDO as a close associate of Putin, and has long supported Kremlin objectives through the bank.  He has previously accused the West of waging economic war against Russia through sanctions. He has already been sanctioned by the US and EU. Alexei Miller The chief executive of Russian energy company Gazprom is one of the most important executives supporting the Kremlin. Miller served under Putin in the s when the now-President was deputy mayor in St Petersburg. UK officials believe he has been going along his career trajectory with Putin since the Russian President was was deputy mayor of St Petersburg in s.  Miller has already been sanctioned by the US. Nikolai Tokarev Nikolai Tokarev is president of the Russia state-owned pipeline company Transneft. He served alongside Putin in the KGB in Dresden, East Germany, in the s. They have remained closely associated ever since. Tokarev has been sanctioned by the US and EU. Dmitri Lebedev Dmitri Lebedev is the chairman of the Board of Directors of Bank Rossiya. The UK designated Bank Rossiya, widely considered to be the Kremlin’s private bank, on  February . Lebedev was sanctioned by the US in . title: zelenskys defiant behaviour proves vladimir
story: Zelenskys defiant behaviour proves Vladimir Putin cannot win war in UkraineAs he addressed MPs in the House of Commons and talked about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky pointed out he was talking to everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world.Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky addressed MPs in the House of Commons via videolink Image: PAopinionByBrian Reade:,  Mar |commentsIn a political chamber that has too often witnessed cowardice here was the face of courage. You had to pinch yourself to realise that until very recently our Prime Minister spent every appearance here refusing to admithe’d held parties in his own flat. Yet here was the leader of a major European country being brutally honest about the devastating shelling of flats by an invading army in cities three hours away from the UK on a budget flight.As Volodymyr Zelensky outlined the crimes being unleashed by a “gangster state” the assembled MPs, wearing headphones and grim expressions on the packed benches, gave the big, hushed room the feel of a war crimes court. Hopefully a modern-day Nuremberg awaits Zelensky’s nemesis, Putin. The Ukrainian leader pointed out he was addressing everyone in the UK, as a fellow citizen of the world. And dressed in his trademark green tee-shirt he looked the part. As he gave us a breakdown of the horrors happening in his homeland, with eyes heavy and face drawn, it could have been someone you’d just met talking you through a personal tragedy. If anything encapsulates the Spirit of Ukraine it is this man. If anything says Putin won’t win it is Zelensky’s defiant demeanour. His presence in our parliament, like his message, was simple. It said: “I’m not hiding, I’m not afraid. We will endure.” Other world leaders have addressed Westminster before such as Barack Obama and Angela Merkel. But whereas they felt like they were taking part in some mutual admiration ceremony, this felt real. It felt urgent.  Whenever we turn our TVs on we see voiceless children and pensioners scrambling for their lives, and here was their voice. Here was their living symbol of resistance. Here was a man telling us, from the heart, why we cannot further abandon those innocent civilians who do not deserve their plight. Yet who do deserve our protection. It made you ashamed of the listening government’s pathetic response to the refugee crisis, with the pitul amount of visas they’ve handed out and the bureaucratic hoops they are making desperate people jump through to get them. Zelensky is what we hope we would all be when put under the most intolerable of pressure. Cool and courageous. This former actor is suddenly making speeches on the hoof that the finest dramatists would be proud of. For his British audience he evoked Shakespeare, saying there was no question of whether Ukraine’s fate was “to be or not to be.” It was to be. He pushed the British patriotic buttons even harder when he summoned the spirit of Winston Churchill, vowing to fight the Russian enemy in the fields and in the forests. Johnson gave a knowing smile of recognition when he heard that. Priti Patel sat there smirking by his side throughout, as she does. And when Zelensky talked about dramatically increasing sanctions, Rishi Sunak’s eyebrows twitched as he did the sums.  To hear him speak is to realise how badly Putin underestimated the will of Ukrainians. It’s the sense of calm he projects that has kept his nation going in the face of horrendous oppression. At the end of his -minute speech, during a long standing ovation, some MPs wiped away tears. It was a moving performance which humbled all who watched and gave us hope. Because the longer Zelensky survives and the more he draws standing ovations from parliaments and wet cheeks from millions watching on TV, the more he becomes Putin’s worst nightmare. story: Cheeky great-gran credits Jägerbombs, tequila  pizza for making nd birthdayLily Bullen recently celebrated her nd birthday, but despite her old age, she still loves a good knees-up and chooses to mark every birthday with a tequila shotByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments A tequila-loving great-grandmother has shared her own personal secrets for how sheaposs made it to celebrating her nd birthday - and it sounds like an awful lot of fun.Lily Bullen recently celebrated her birthday with family and friends, with her usual party trick of downing a shot of tequila, which she says helps her to love her le.Despite making it to age that most of us will never reach, Lily is still full of le and loves treating herself with Dominoaposs pizza, Greggs sausage rolls and cream cakes.Still one for adventure, on her th birthday Lily even tried ice-skating for the first time, and sheaposll never turn down a good knees-up.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Party-loving Lily, who has three grown-up children, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, says the secret to longevity is to enjoy le. She said: Live one day at a time because tomorrow is never promised. On February , Lily celebrated turning  with a party hosted by all her friends and family at Breme House in Bromsgrove, Worcestershire. The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook Her granddaughter, Holly West, , from Worcester, said: Her favourite pastime when she can is to watch her great-grandchildren play. At the age of  the home took Nan ice skating for the first time in her le at Webb’s, she loved it. She had a surprise birthday party for her th birthday, where she did a tequila shot, she also did a Jägerbomb and tequila shot at our wedding in .The world went into lockdown the week after her birthday. She’s been reminiscing about the Birmingham bombings with the Russia Ukraine news. Her philosophy is to live one day at a time because tomorrow is never promised. title: i could always tell kids
story: I could always tell when my kids were lying - so I became top private investigatorSharon Sutila, , from the US, says her kids stopped trying to lie to her after realising she would always suss them out - so she decided to turn her skills into a successful careerSharon says her kids dont bother lying to her anymore as they know theyll be found out Image: PA Real LeByJoe PagnelliJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsA mum who became an expert in detecting the fibs of her children says itaposs given her the skills she needed to become a top private investigator. Sharon Sutila, , is a mum-of-two with a sixth sense for when people are telling porkies - something she claims to have learned from raising -year-old Marissa and -year-old Tesla. Now the CEO of Cluso Investigation, which she founded in , Sharon puts her super sleuth skills to work uncovering secrets people would rather keep buried. Sharon, who describes herself as a human lie detector, says her kids donapost even bother lying to her anymore, as they know theyaposll get caught. The mum from the US state of Delaware said: My skillset means I stay as neutral as I can, evenI don’t trust what they are telling me. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here I don’t call them out, I try to stay cool and find outthey are telling me the truth, but I always find out. They are aware of that, so they have grown up knowing it is always better to tell the truth. If theyaposve ever told me they don’t have homework when they do, they know I will find out about it.She described an incident when Marissa was little and she tried to conceal a mark sheaposd made in the house from her mum. Sharon says she not only found out about the mark, but also went as far as showing her daughter the New York state laws to let her know lying has consequences. She said: I think it scared her to death!  The mum reckons she honed her detective skills when she was just  years old and channelled her favourite literary characters, Sherlock Holmes and Nancy Drew. After a classroom bully smashed her favourite record and wrote her a nasty note, Sharon was determined to expose them to her teacher. She found out who the culprit was by comparing their handwriting to the homework of her peers. After graduating from university in , Sharon shunned the family business in fishing and seafood to embark upon a career in tech for IBM. There, she realised she could use her coding skills to suss out new potential employees - and she pointed out those who werenapost telling the truth on their CVs.  People had put degrees that they had never taken and qualications that they never had, she said. And when her bosses discovered her skills, she became an integral part of the companyaposs international operation. Sharon said: I wanted to know more about the person, or I couldn’t be sure they weren’t lying to me. I absolutely love research, figuring things out and problem solving. I like challenges. Now working as a private investigator, Sharon says sheaposs skilled at finding out things about people from the comfort of her own home - as long as she has a computer. She said: I mostly work on allowing people to tell me what they want to tell me first. And I’ll try to seethey are being honest.  While Sharon enjoys her work, sheaposs had to put up with her fair share of threats from people who sheaposs exposed. She said: I have been threatened. A man told me he was going to come into my house. But I’m not going to let someone stop me from doing my job just because they are being aggressive. I’m not going to stop what I do because of a threat. Sharon has now penned a novel based on some of her experiences working in a male-dominated industry, called The Healing. She said: Championing equality for women is my lelong passion. Challenging gender bias and the stereotyping of women is critically important to combat the issue. I wrote my book by starting my character with a lot of my own background. I grew up in the same time frame as the book and went through the very same gender norms, which can mean women canapost do or achieve certain things. In the book, the character starts in the same way I did - being told I couldnapost follow my own path. And she is trying to find her purpose in the world. Sharonaposs top  signs someone might be lying: . If someone uses the word aposhonestlyapos they might be hiding something. . If people who start to over-explain situations - the truth is often much simpler. . If someone is immediately defensive or turns to anger when they are asked a question. . If someone knows too much about a subject, as liars will often do research. . If people react strangely when you tell them you are going to check the information they have given you.Do you have a story to share  Email jesssica.taylor@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Sherlock HolmesParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i teach woman how better
story: I teach women how to have better orgasms - one man blamed me for his orceEvie Plumb, , says her first sexual experiences were "anti-climactic" due to her not knowing how to ask for what she wanted in the bedroom - and after getting two STIs, she set about helping other women have good sexEvie says she wants women to unlearn the shame they feel when they express sexual desires Image: PA Real LeByLouise LazellJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsAn influencer who had two STIs at the age of  is on a mission to teach women about sexual pleasure - and claims her advice is so good, it led to a woman orcing her husband. Evie Plumb, now , realised she hadnapost been taught much about STIs after she contracted both the HPV virus and chlamydia. The entrepreneur from Bishopaposs Stortford, Herts, recalled first realising she had contracted an infection when she had genital warts. She said: “I convinced myself I was dying and I was filled with shame. After Googling her condition, Evie said she felt even worse - and realised thereaposs not much information available about STIs online. Once sheaposd been treated for both conditions, Evie decided it was high time women were more educated about sex - including how to reach orgasm. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters hereCreating a community called the Clitorati on Instagram, Evie began posting funny but informative explainers on everything from sex toys to the G-spot.During the first lockdown in  she launched a podcast interviewing sex experts around the world - and even released her own brand of lubricant. Now, she has , followers on her Cliterally The Best Instagram page, who are keen to learn more about womenaposs sexual pleasure. She said: I think the biggest thing is all about unlearning and learning instead to own your pleasure and self-pleasure, because there is so much shame around this.  As well as talking about the fun aspects of sex, she also uses her  to educate women on the HPV virus - which is the name for  dferent strains of virus that affect the mouth, throat or genital area.According to the NHS, most of us will contract at least one of these strains in our letime.Evie, who is in a long-term relationship with boyfriend Josh, , said: “When you are little, sex education is so shame-based and you are told everything is bad, like getting pregnant. You learn nothing about enjoyment – it’s all, aposDon’t do this and don’t do that.apos “It takes a while to unlearn it all.”  She looks back on her childhood in explaining why she was so interested in liberating women in their sexual desires. Evie recalls being slut shamed in a society that made girls feel wrong for showing an interest in sex and pleasure. She added her lack of knowledge around the female orgasm meant her early sexual experiences were fumbling and anti-climactic - literally.Evie said: The first time you have sex, you are told you’ll have these orgasms and then there’s no focus on female pleasure. You are waiting for a moment of epiphany that is unlikely to happen.I used to focus on what men thought about me and what they wanted. Now, Iaposm not selfish, but I do stuff for me, not for other people.You have to learn to ask for what you want and advocate for your own pleasure. After her Cliterally The Best Instagram page took off, Evie launched a website where women can learn about gynaecological health and pick up sex tips.Since launching the pages, Evie says sheaposs been inundated with messages of thanks from women who are having better sex. I had one woman in her s come up to me and thank me so much for recommending this sex toy, because she had her first orgasm, she said. It makes it feel worthwhile. As Evie has grown in popularity, sheaposs been dubbed the sexual pleasure fairy godmother. She is now qualied to teach sex education - but insists she is constantly researching and learning more about sex, gender and intimacy.Although she was initially apprehensive about talking to her family about her new enterprise, Evie is now proud of her work.She said: “When I originally launched the podcast with my friend, I didn’t tell my parents what it was about, but as it grew, I explained and they were a little hesitant but just wanted to know I was safe.“But as it got bigger and I started to have press mentions, they were happy to learn about it and have been very supportive ever since.” However, despite receiving plenty of support for her work, Evie still has to put up with slut-shaming by trolls - and says she receives unsolicited X-rated images from men at least twice a week.She said: “I’m numb to them now, but they used to make me very, very angry.Sadly, there is no reasoning with these people. It’s a power thing and you have no consent in whether or not you see it.”She claims she was even contacted by a man who blamed Evie when his we wanted a orce - because he wasnapost sexually fulfilling her. Evie said: “He tried to blame me because she mentioned my page. She told him to, aposGo to this and learn what I meanapos.” As Evieaposs movement grows, she hopes to also move into the role of sex ambassador for schools and to design a sex education course for kids.She said: My dream is to do a course to become a psychosexual therapist and turn Cliterally The Best into a hub people come to for information and therapy.I want therapy to be more accessible and to make the website a home for sex and learning.I would like to see the conversation around sex education become a normal thing, to be spoken about as openly and without shame. Do you have a story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON STDsSex educationOrgasmsG-spotSex toys" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: my mum picked out date
story: Exclusive: My mum picked out my date weeks before she died - now I know hes The OneWhen Laura McNally partnered with charity Marie Curie at work, she was struck by the incredible support they offered to people at the end of their lives - but she never knew how much shed end up needing them herselfLaura started dating Peter after her mum encouraged her to message him Image: Laura McNallyByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Mar |commentsBased in London and with a successful marketing career, Laura McNally was living le “in the fast lane.” The now -year-old had spent more than a decade living in the capital after moving from her hometown of Cookstown, Northern Ireland. She’d been working for supermarket chain Spar and had been given responsibility for its partnership with the charity Marie Curie. “My role was to promote the partnership in Spar stores,” Laura tells The Mirror. And while she worked closely with the charity in her career, she never had any idea how its nurses would end up touching her le.When the first coronavirus lockdown came into effect, Laura decided to move back to Cookstown to look after her parents, who were struggling with poor health.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Her dad Emmet had been suffering from ongoing heart problems, while her mum Ailish was battling bowel cancer. “I thought, ‘They’re going to need help’. I worried for them. Dad had been poorly for a number of years, and at the time my mum was going through chemo,” she explains. Emmet and Ailish, who had met when they were just  years old, had been married for more than three decades and were an inspiration to Laura. “I grew up with a modest childhood but it was a happy le. It wasn’t filled with big extravagant things,” she says. Laura describes her dad, who worked as a taxi driver, as someone who “lit up a room.” She says: “My dad was very down to earth. He loved le. He had a huge big smile and his laugh was contagious.”  Good with advice, Emmet’s taxi was likened to a confession box because his passengers often confided in him. “He’d never tell us anything though. He knew everything everyone was doing in town but he kept it to himself,” Laura says. But while he never gossiped about others, Laura says her dad often gushed about his daughter to passengers. “I’d come home and people would know all about me - he’d talk about me all the time. I think he was proud of me,” she says. Despite his lust for le, Emmet’s physical health was declining and he’d suffered from heart problems for several years. When Laura moved back to Cookstown she knew he would need help looking after Ailish while she had chemotherapy.  She describes her mum as the “rock who held everything together” in the family. “She loved to travel - I think that’s where I get my adventurous streak from,” Laura says. “She was more like a friend sometimes, I’d have told her anything.” Growing up holding her parents in such high regard, Laura says it was dficult to see them in ailing health - but she cherished the time she spent with them during lockdown. In the summer of  Emmet’s health took a turn for the worse and he ended up in hospital. “He started to really deteriorate and he was in the hospital for nearly three months,” Laura recalls.  “He was in and out of ICU so I told the doctors thatthis was only going in one direction I’d prefer to have him at home. He was such a homely man.” At the end of August, Emmet was brought back to the family home where he was visited by Marie Curie nurses every day. “He was such a proud Irishman, and even in his last days those nurses helped him keep his dignity,” Laura recalls. “To be that vulnerable with your we and daughter in the room is hard, but they supported him with a pain-free ending. They made sure he was really comfortable.” Emmet sadly passed away on  September  at just  years old. Although Laura and Ailish were devastated, they were grateful for the support the nurses had given them during his last days. As Emmet was laid to rest, Ailish and Laura came together with her three brothers to give him as traditional a funeral as they could while social distancing rules were in place.  And while Laura drew strength from a supportive family, the next few months were tough for her and her mum - who was still battling cancer. “We originally found out mum had cancer after she’d visited my oldest brother in Australia,” Laura recalls. “She got pains in her stomach and they thought it was appendicitis, so she had an operation while she was out there. “But when she got home she had a follow-up. She was diagnosed with bowel cancer and it was stage .” Laura says Ailish had a few successful operations to clear ious tumours, but over the years the cancer had continued to spread. By the time Laura had gone home to see her parents during lockdown, Ailish’s care was palliative.  And just months after Emmet’s death, Ailish and Laura received the news they were dreading. Laura recalls: “We sat down with the consultant on Zoom at the end of February and he said the cancer was spreading. My mum asked how long she had and he replied, ‘You’ve got until Easter’. “Mum had just celebrated her th birthday and she looked well. She didn’t look like someone who was dying of cancer. “I said to the consultant, ‘Do you know when Easter is  It’s only six weeks away’. And he said, ‘Yeah, six weeks’.” From that moment on, Laura says she went into “autopilot,” thinking only of her mum.  “Everything I did was for her. She was my priority,” Laura says. As Ailish began to deteriorate, she and Laura began to talk openly about how she wanted her le to end. “We talked about her potentially going into a hospice but we have a huge family, and with Covid restricting visitors, we decided it was best for her to be at home,” Laura says. “She deteriorated slowly, but the Marie Curie nurses helped her too. Mum knew she was dying and the fear and anxiety were very tough for us all.” Laura recalls the nurses arriving at the family home to take care of Ailish and askingthey had the wrong address - because they’d only been there nine months before caring for Emmet. But she doesn’t know how she’d have got through it all without their support.  “They were like walking angels,” she says. Meanwhile, Laura devoted all her time to be with her mum and refused to leave her side. She says: “People had to force me to go to bed. I didn’t want to sleep because I thoughtI slept, that was less time I’d have with mum.” In the last weeks of her le, Ailish laughed and joked with her daughter as they had always done - and even had fun talking about Laura’s love le. “Mum was in bed a lot and we’d be up all hours talking about my future and what my wedding day would be like.“It must have been am and I was on Facebook Dating. We came across a guy called Peter and mum said, ‘Message him, he looks lovely’.”After following her mum’s advice, Laura got chatting to Peter, who was also from Cookstown, and soon after he asked her out on a date.“I was reluctant to go on a date,” Laura recalls. “Mum was my priority and I worried something would happen while I was out.” But friends and family convinced Laura to go, arguing she needed to do something for herself. And after spending a few hours on a walk with Peter, Laura realised she’d made the right decision. The pair realised they’d both lived fairly close by in London for years - and their paths had almost crossed several times before. Although the pair clicked instantly, Laura was keen to get home to see Ailish after a few hours - but she said Peter was understanding from the beginning. “He stuck by me and understood - most guys wouldn’t,” she said. Over the next days and weeks, Peter checked in with Laura every single day - eventhe pair hadn’t seen each other. Sadly, on  June , Ailish passed away at home - and less than a year after losing her dad, Laura had to plan her mum’s funeral too.  Once again, her tight-knit family rallied around to support her while she grieved - and this time, Laura had Peter to lean on too. “He came to the wake and was introduced to everyone - my whole family was there,” Laura says. “When I came back to the house after the funeral and everyone had gone, there was just silence. It’s probably the worst feeling I’ve ever had in my whole le. That’s when the grief takes over. “But Peter was there for me.” After losing both her parents in a short space of time, Laura began to re-evaluate things in her le and made some big decisions. She decided to quit her job and set up her own marketing company, giving herself the freedom to work whenever and wherever she wanted - and fitting in Peter’s work around that. “I live le very dferently now,” Laura says. “I wake up now and it hits me every day like a ton of bricks. But I have a choice: I can stay in bed all day or I can get up and do something positive every day, evenit’s something little.  “Don’t get me wrong, I still have down days, but I think, ‘what would my parents thinkthey were watching me now’ ” As Laura and Peter navigate a new way of living their lives, Laura is keen to encourage people to talk about their grief - admitting that telling people about what her parents were like is incredibly cathartic for her. “Over the last two years during the pandemic, so many more people have lost loved ones,” she says. Laura adds it’s important to acknowledge those we have lost - and she’s taking part in Marie Curie’s National Day of Reflection on  March to honour them. While le is ing to some kind of normal as Covid restrictions are lted, the charity wants to acknowledge those who are still grappling with grief after losing people during the pandemic. It will hold a minute’s silence at midday in tribute to those who died and will also be hosting a Wall of Reflection. For Laura, who holds the charity close to her heart, the day will provide some comfort as she remembers Emmet and Ailish.Do you have a love story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcShe says: “Before I lost my parents I used to thinksomeone lost a loved one you shouldn’t talk about it for fear of upsetting them. “But now,I get an opportunity, I talk about them. I miss them loads and I love them to bits.” To find out more about the National Day of Reflection on  March, please visit mariecurie.org.uk dayofreflection To support the Great Daffodil Appeal this month, please visit: mariecurie.org.uk Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveBowel cancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: britains loneliest lion could moved
story: Britains loneliest lion could be moved from his home after second playmate diesBailey has been left all alone after his -year-old cousin Naja was put down last week following a rapid deterioration in her healthBailey is alone now after his cousins died Image: Shanice Moore   SWNS.COMByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A lion thought to be Britainaposs loneliest could be relocated from his home of  years to be with lionesses, after losing his second female companion in just two years.Bailey the lion has been king of the pride at Colchester Zoo in Essex since  when he arrived with his cousins Naja and Malika. But Bailey has been left all alone, after -year-old Naja was put down last week following a rapid deterioration in her health. It comes less than  months after the pair lost Malika in October , at the age of . Now, staff at Colchester Zoo are keeping a close eye on lonely Bailey and are even considering relocating him to another zoo with a pride of lionesses.  In a statement issued on their website earlier this week, zoo staff wrote: We would like to thank all our visitors for the overwhelming support that we have received following the devastating news of the passing of our female lioness, Naja, on Friday, March . We have received many kind messages towards our staff, as well as concerns about our male lion, Bailey. Bailey’s health and welfare is our top priority and, whilst our Animal Care Team continues to monitor him daily, discussions have been put in place by the Animal Care Management Team regarding Bailey’s future at Colchester Zoo. The team are currently exploring bringing in a female lioness for Bailey, but this option is reliant on a lioness being available at one of our neighbouring zoos. However, given Bailey’s age, introducing a female at this stage in his le could prove too stressful. The team are also exploring relocating Bailey to another zoo with a pride of lionesses. This would be dependent on another organisation having the space to house Bailey and the move alone could prove too much. Bailey has become a big part of the Colchester Zoo family and parting with him feels almost impossible and irresponsible. Read more Our Animal Care Team will continue to monitor Bailey’s mental and physical welfare over the next few weeks. It’s our responsibility to ensure that Bailey’s welfare is at the forefront of any decision made, which may include letting him live out the rest of his le here at the zoo by himself. A previous statement last week paid tribute to Naja, writing: Naja was truly one of a kind. Her personality and character set her aside from any other animal we’ve had the pleasure to work with. Naja had a gentle side where she would interact with her keepers, but very quickly changed when food was available! Not only will all the staff at Colchester Zoo miss Naja, but she also leaves behind our male lion, Bailey. Bailey and Naja were cousins along with Naja’s sister, Malika, who passed away back in . All three lions had a strong bond, with the bond between Bailey and Naja made even stronger with the loss of Malika. title: couple 31 dogs left devastated
story: Couple with  dogs left devastated after being forced out their homeSue Bell and Dave Haywood run the UKs only dalmatian sanctuary and have issued an urgent plea for help to find a new home near Lancashire big enough to house their  dogsDave Haywood with some of his dalmatians Image: SWNSByLauren BeavisLottie GibbonsPaige Freshwater:,  Mar |commentsA couple with  dogs have issued a desperate plea for help after being forced out their home.Sue Bell, , and Dave Haywood, , run the UKaposs only dalmatian sanctuary.They treat the rehomed dogs like kids - letting them live inside their converted stable and allowing them on sofas and beds. But they have put out an urgent plea for help to find a new home, close to Lancashire, for their family - as their isolated location has become uninhabitable. DAS Dalmatians is currently based just outside Newton Abbott, Devon - or the middle of nowhere, as they describe it.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.The property gets flooded every time it rains, and the roads are so bad that emergency services cannot reach it, reports the LiverpoolEcho.Sue said: We live in a stable that is down a bridleway. No one will deliver anything.aposaposA few weeks ago we had an electrical fire, and we were very lucky that Dave and I were awake otherwise who knows what could have happened.aposaposThe couple were forced to stop taking in new dogs last month due to the state of their premises. But they want to keep to continue on their mission to help dalmatians, so they are now appealing for dog-friendly potential landlords to get in touch. The couple currently live in a triple stable, with a kitchen, two bedrooms, a bathroom and a lounge - which is usually filled with dalmatians. And le with a pack of dogs is tough - as it means getting up before sunrise to let the dogs out into their field. Sue said: Biscuit likes to sing to us at .am every morning until one of us gets up and lets him onto our bed. Thankfully heaposs the only one that does that. The dogs donapost live in kennels or cages - instead lounging about on the beds and sofas around their converted stable home.  Dinnertime consists of shovelling out kg of dog biscuits every day, with Sue on hand to make sure every dog gets enough. Sue, a full-time dog mum, said: Le with these dogs is madness - but I wouldnapost have it any other way. You have to be dotty to have so many spotties. Iaposve always loved dogs but I love dalmatians because they are dferent. The first dog the couple helped was a six-month-old puppy who was being sold as part of a drug deal. Sue said: The poor little mite was very skinny, dirty and stunk of smoke. We have been asked to help more and more dogs over the years and have never wanted to stop. The couple rehome the dalmatians that are able to live a normal le after being assessed and rehabilitated but take in the kids that cannot be rehomed. She said: These pups stay with us forever being loved and having the best we can give them. We also help dogs that other rescues say no to. If a dog needs our help, I will do whatever I can do to helpwe have room but sadly at the moment, we can not help dogs that are threatened to be euthanised as we do not have room to keep them separated while being assessed.  The eldest of their dogs are Zakky and Zena, aged  who has been with Sue for two years. The pair are brother and sister whose owner died and left them on their own. Sue said: Zakky has a long bite history and bit Dave on meeting him - which can happen quite often with new problem kids. Zakky took a while to realise he didn’t have to bite anymore and now is one of the family and very loving. Zena now has dementia but still knows how to con her Dad into sharing his food with her. We stopped them from being separated - another rescue was going to split them up but they were  years old, it would have been awful for them to do that so they came here. They need to find a new home soon so they can take more dogs - and ideally, one that is in a more suitable location, more easily accessible for food deliveries and vet visits. Sue said: There are no kennels and as the dogs are free-range, they are very happy and don’t bark. Keeping them in a home environment is much better for their well-being. We live in a stable that is down a bridleway. No one will deliver anything. We are on the side of a valley, so every time it rains it floods us. The roof has holes in it so we are exposed to the elements. In summer it is so dusty - I get such bad chest infections. The road is so narrow and bumpy that emergency services are also unable to reach us. aposaposOn Sunday we had an electrical fire, and we were very lucky that Dave and I were awake otherwise who knows what could have happened.aposapos Sue continued: People donapost realise that the dogs are so quiet because they donapost live in kennels - they donapost make a noise. We have so many wonderful dogs that need our care, a huge mixture of ages - and we donapost want them to live in mud anymore.aposapos Sue and Dave, who run the sanctuary full-time, are ideally after a long term let, within a few hours drive of Morecambe Bay in a rural setting with at least an acre of land and a yard.You can donate to the sanctuary here. Do you have a dog story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. title: dad 47 attend living wake
story: Dad, , will attend his own living wake as one of two dying wishesGordon Airlie was diagnosed with Acute myeloid leukaemia at Ninewells Hospital in April  and initially told he likely had just -hours to liveGordon, , and Audrey Airlie, , from DundeeByKaitlin EastonReporter:,  Mar |commentsA terminally-ill father delivered the devastating news that he had just weeks left to live, has now organised his own “living wake”.Gordon Airlie was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia at Ninewells Hospital in April  and initially told he likely had just -hours to live.The -year-old had suffered from recurring sickness, body pain and blood blisters and had noticed blood in his urine and faeces.The dad fought on, with things looking up as he received a stem cell donation at the end of the year. However, the aggressive cancer ed and at the beginning of this month Gordon was told he likely had just weeks to live,The Daily Recordreports.Gordon, from Dundee, had two dying wishes - to marry partner of -years Audrey, , and host a living wake for himself.  Initially both events were planned for March  but doctors advised the family to move the wedding forward and within  hours they had planned the event at their family home. Step-daughter Kirsty McLean, , said: We got the blood test results on Friday and doctors said the disease was progressing fast and he might not make it to the wedding. Within  hours we had organised a wedding to happen at the house. We were running all over town trying to arrange everything and get cakes. We decorated the house and stuff as well with balloons. It was just close family and friends that attended. Weaposre now planning his living wake at the moment and waiting on another blood test to see how much the cancer has progressed.I had personally never heard of a living wake before and didnapost know it was a thing but he wants to get all his pals together one last time to say goodbye. The living wake is currently planned for March  at Gordonaposs favourite local, Club  in Dundee, but the family expect they will need to bring the event forward again. A band has been booked for the entertainment and a photo booth and photographer have been booked to capture precious memories. Loved ones will also be encouraged to write down their favourite memories with Gordon to share at the special event.  Gordon, who is step-dad to Kirsty, Tami and Dana, and dad to Kerr, is also hoping to have a final outing with his grandchildren. I donapost know how Iaposll manage at the wake, all my sisters and I have done is cry, Kirsty said. We are all just in so much shock - we couldnapost believe it - because he did get the all clear in January. My mum is one of the strongest women Iaposve ever met. Itaposs just her there on her own trying to do everything for him so I think it will really hit her after. Dave Mack from Club said they would make sure Gordon, nicknamed Googs, had a very special evening. Googs is a very well respected member of the Club and dart team,” he said. “Heaposs a good friend of mine as well and has been here for years as a leader of the darts team. For his living wake we will assist his family and make sure we give him something very special. He is such a great guy - he popped in the other week to see everyone and the club was full of people wanting to hi. Weaposre going to pull out all the stops for him to give him a great farewell. The family have scraped together so they could pay for the last minute wedding and are currently paying for the wake with their own cash. Tami has launched a fundraising page to go towards the cost of the wake as leftover cash will go to Gordonaposs final outing with his grandchildren.Donations to the page can be madehere .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsCancerLeukaemia" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news delta-omicron-covid-hybrid-detected-"Stealth Omicron: What is the BA. iant BySam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar |comments A Delta-Omicron coronavirus hybrid has been detected in the UK as experts warn the government it shouldnapost be ignored. Dubbed ‘Deltacron’, the new French-based strain combines both lineages. However, its severity is not yet known.But there is a warning that immunity is waning in the elderly as one scientist added that it is aposthe real thingapos. The World Health Organisation said it is apostracking and discussingapos the iant following research into the strain. There is no clear data yet to show whether Deltacron is more infectious than its predecessors. Health chiefs told The Sun a very small number of cases have been detected in Britain, but more details are to be reported in a briefing on Friday.Aris Katzourakis, professor of evolution and genomics at the University of Oxford, said: “It is one to keep an eye on. This one is legit. Dr Stephen Grfin, a virologist at the University of Leeds, said: “Whilst it doesn’t seem to have taken off as a dominant strain yet, this could be due to a very slow start based upon seeding density - the number of initial cases, he said.“There are multiple scenarios that can play out here in terms of what this means for people that become infected as this combination of viral proteins may behave dferently to either parent. “The French cluster appears to be a validated occurrence where a recombination event has given rise to a virus fit enough to circulate.Last month, the UK Health Security Agency announced it was investigating a iant named “Delta x Omicron Recombinant ”.However, it is not knownthis is linked to the French-based Deltacron.  Hospitalisation in the UK have shown an aposuptickapos in the past fortnight, data shows. The ZOE Covid Symptom Study estimates around , people are catching Covid each day - a  per cent hike in one week. Study co-founder Professor Tim Spector said: “The ‘official’ UK dashboard rate that continues to provide a misleading picture of the pandemic in the UK and should be scrapped. “The major increase in new cases across the country and in the elderly is a worry, especially as we now see an uptick in hospitalisations for the first time. “This increase was predicted when all restrictions were lted. “We are likely to continue to see high infection and prevalence rates of  in  people for the foreseeable future.” Dr Jenny Harries, head of the UKHSA, said: “The increasing presence of the BA. sub-lineage of Omicron and the recent slight increase in infections in those over  show that the pandemic is not over and that we can expect to see Covid circulating at high levels.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON University of OxfordCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dock worker who held martial
story: Worker fired for teaching martial arts class while bed-bound with spine injuryMichael Connorton had been off work for more than four months when his bosses were given a tip-off that he was instructing Hapkido classesMichael Connorton at Teesside Hapkido, in Middlesbrough Image: Evening GazetteByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A dockyard worker was sacked after his bosses hired private investigators and caught him teaching martial arts classes while he was off work injured, a tribunal heard.Michael Connorton told his managers he was in so much pain after suffering a spinal injury that all he could do was lay in bed or on his sofa. But after the port worker had been off work for more than four months, his bosses were given a tip-off that he was instructing Hapkido classes. The bosses at PD Ports hired private investigators to carry out aposcovert surveillanceapos on Mr Connorton - and were provided with photos and videos of him teaching the Korean martial art to a class of . The covert recordings showed him driving to class, adopting aposfighting stancesapos, wielding training swords, demonstrating combat moves and carrying heavy objects aposwithout obvious signs of discomfortapos.When the  year old was summoned to explain himself, he claimed he aposcouldnapost rememberaposhe attended any other classes while off injured because his medication gave him aposmemory lossapos. Mr Connorton was sacked for gross misconduct but has tried to sue PD Ports for disability discrimination - however now his case has been thrown out at an employment tribunal. Mr Connorton, who has been training in martial arts since he was , is a th Dan black belt in Hapkido and has won tournaments in the discipline. Alongside others he set up his own class about  years ago and now teaches at Hapkido Teesside in Middlesbrough. The tribunal, held in Newcastle, heard Mr Connorton worked for PD Ports, one of the UKaposs leading port groups operating  dock sites nationwide.  He was a dockyard worker at the companyaposs Teesport site on the River Tees, North Yorks, and worked for the firm since . The tribunal heard Mr Connorton was signed off sick in October  after suffering a aposspasm of painapos at work caused by a degenerative disc bulging from his spine. In February  he told Occupational Health - who visited him at home due to him claiming he was in too much pain to travel - that he was unable to do anything other than read, which he could do while lying on his bed or sofa. On February , Mr Connortonaposs bosses received a report he was aposactually teaching his martial arts classapos. The next day he told Occupational Health his pain had not improved, he could not drive and his symptoms were causing aposlow mood and fatigueapos. However, the same evening he drove to his martial arts class. The private investigators discovered he drove to and attended the Hapkido class on February ,  and  - and they filmed him on each visit. A tribunal report said:The investigators provided PD Ports with a report and photographs and a video recording. Amongst other things, the investigatorsapos report refers to Mr Connorton, without any obvious signs of discomfort or ailment, driving to and from the class. [It shows him] rising from the floor after conducting stretching exercises with a class of approximately  people, assisting with student development, lting a metal barrier and then a five-a-side football goal. [It shows him] carrying a number of training swords and walking approximately  metres carrying a large sports bag holstered over his right shoulder, providing instruction, contributing to martial arts activity instruction including adopting a fighting stance and shouting to all the class that he was about undertake aposmock testsapos for those who wanted to practice. The photographs are supportive of the above in that they show him arriving at the class driving himself in his car, walking without any apparent discomfort, carrying a bag and equipment and moving barriers and a football goal. In the class itself the claimant is shown wearing his Hapkido suit, exercising, conducting exercises, kneeling and demonstrating martial arts moves and techniques. In light of this report, PD Ports was concerned at the apparent disparity between what he was reporting and what he was doing, and that he was not being truthful. During a disciplinary process, Mr Connorton was shown the images but said he could not rememberhe had attended other classes between October  and February  aposdue to drugsapos. Mr Connorton said he was aposnot instructing but was showing and guiding othersapos, which the tribunal ruled was aposlittle more than semanticsapos. He claimed the items he carried were light and he went to the class to improve his mental health but was still in pain. He said he had not done anything aposstrenuousapos. He was sacked in March , with bosses citing apossignicant doubts with regard to your honesty and integrityapos. Employment Judge John Morris ruled the dismissal was fair and had nothing to do with him being disabled as a result of his injury. He said: The reason for [Mr Connortonaposs] dismissal was his lack of candour and frankness throughout the disciplinary process and his failure to provide a satisfactory explanation for his attendance at the Hapkido classes. The key point for [PD Ports] was the aposdisconnectapos between what he had said to Occupational Health on February  and the information from the surveillance team. title: dog nicknamed mr ugly searching
story: Dog nicknamed Mr Ugly searching for new home after being found alone on mountainFive-year-old Vincent has become known as Mr Ugly at Blind Dogs Rescue UK - but is hoping to shake his unfortunate nickname when he secures a new home in the UKVincent is searching for a new home Image: Blind Dog Rescue UKByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsAfter being nicknamed Mr Ugly, volunteers lost a little hope that this poor pooch will find his forever family.The five-year-old dog, who is completely blind, was taken in by Blind Dog Rescue UK after spending a year wandering alone on a mountainside.He was in a really bad way with hardly any fur on his body when he was picked up by the rescue. Actually called Vincent, the lonely dog is hoping somebody in the UK will come forward to offer in a place in their home. A spokesperson from Blind Dog Rescue UK said: Introducing the gorgeous Vincent who has the unfortunate nickname of Mr Ugly at the shelter.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.He is leishmania positive which caused his blindness and will need regular medication and blood tests for this for his entire le.Since being rescued from the mountains, Vincentaposs fur has completely grown back, meaning he can soon leave his Mr Ugly nickname behind. He has been described as a clam, sweet, and sociable dog who enjoys spending time with humans. New places and situations are stressful for him but he gets used to it quickly, said the spokesperson. In the shelter, he is dominant with other male dogs but he is friendly and playful with female dogs.Vincent would love a patient home where he can learn to trust his new family and can live with a female dog for company. Vincent is currently living in a rescue in Greece but is ready to fly to the UK once a family is found. Blind Dog Rescue UK works to rehome blind and partially sighted dogs who have been subjected to the “worst of humanity yet still have an astonishing capacity to adapt, love and become perfect ambassadors for blind dogs everywhere”. Many of the dogs in their care have been victims of abuse, neglect, disease or trauma - and struggle to survive in shelters. A Blind Dog Rescue UK statement reads: “It is incredibly dficult for sighted dogs to survive anyof time in these shelters let alone blind or partially sighted dogs. “We need to get to these dogs quickly and secure their immediate release and treatment.“These dogs may have been deliberately blinded, involved in road traffic accidents or long term sufferers of painful conditions such as glaucoma.“They need veterinary care and to be given the safety and comfort of a foster home in which to start healing. “Here they are given love and affection and a warm bed - possibly the first they will have experienced in their letimes. At this point, we are able to start assessing and promoting these wonderful dogs for forever homes.To adopt Vincent, or find out more information about him, contact Blind Dog Rescue UK via their website www.bdruk.org.Do you have a story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: how worried should new covid
story: How worried should we be about new Covid spike as cases surge by % in a weekInfections appear to be rising in over s as the BA. Omicron iant spreads, with experts sounding the alarm that the pandemic is not over yet despite Boris Johnsons Living with Covid plan London Overground" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _BRITAIN-TRANSPORT-RAIL-STRIKE.jpg" width"" "" Commuters, some wearing face coverings due to Covid-, exit a Transport for LondonLondon Overground Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar |commentsThe Covid pandemic is not over yet and the latest surge in cases is a concern, say experts.Infections appear to be rising in older people as socialising increases in the wake of Freedom Day last month, vaccine immunity wanes and BA. - a more transmissible Omicron strain - spreads.Although BA. is more contagious than BA., clinical data does not suggest a signicant dference in disease severity.Wednesday saw recorded infections rise by more than  percent and deaths by two thirds compared to last week, according to data from the Department of Health. Hospital admissions have also risen sharply, with , people in hospitals with the virus on March  and  requiring a mechanical ventilator.The worrying figures come just weeks before the government plans to scrap free lateral flow tests for most people on April .Are you worried by the rise  Have your say in the comment section Free PCR tests will also not be available to people with symptoms as the government implements its aposLiving with Covidapos plan, introduced on February . Data from a study by Imperial College’s React- team shows around one in  peoplein England were infected between February  and March  - with the virus particularly prevalent in people over . The figure was a drop on the . percent recorded between January  and , but was the second-highest rate since the study started in .  The React- data comes from nearly , swabs from homes across England. It shows infections have dropped since the January peak but scientists involved said the R value, or the average number of infected, remained below  for those  and under. But for those  and over it stood at .. Experts are investigating whether hospitalisation rates are being driven by “unshielding”, where some of the most vulnerable people have ed back to normal after two years of self-isolation. Dr Jenny Harries, chief executive of the UK Health Security Agency , told Sky News: These data confirm that cases have declined substantially following the peak of the Omicron wave.However, the increasing presence of the BA. sub-lineage of Omicron and the recent slight increase in infections in those over  show that the pandemic is not over and that we can expect to see COVID circulating at high levels.  Professor Paul Elliot, director of Imperial College Londonaposs React programme, said: At the moment, weaposre possibly seeing the beginning of an uptick, but we donapost know where itaposs going to go. Mark Woolhouse, professor of infectious disease epidemiology at the University of Edinburgh, said it was “impossible to make a sensible prediction” about the size of any BA. wave but the situation needed close monitoring.He told the: “The worry is that it’s hard to see anything happening in the next few weeks that will reverse the growth of BA. unless, that is, people decide on their own account to step up precautions.”Danny Altmann, professor of immunology at Imperial College, said the recent rise was foreseeable. “We’ll see a great deal more of this, along the lines of recent resurgent spikes in Scotland and Hong Kong,” he said. “Caseloads were by no means low or under control as we came out of all mitigations and, when you add in waning immunity and the enhanced transmissibility of BA., it looks like we are in for a dficult period, especially for the elderly.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSDepartment of HealthGrant ShappsHospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i didnt save crazy crufts
story: I didnt save crazy Crufts hero Kratu - he saved me from addiction and abuseTess Swam, , whose book, Incredible Kratu, was published this week, credits her dog with helping her recover after she fell into a spiral of addiction and abuseTess Swan with Kratu Image: DAILY MIRRORByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Mar |comments When Kratu the Romanian rescue dog went rogue during an agility trial at Crufts in  he ended up the star of the show, delighting everyone who watched with his hilarious performance. Chased by owner Tess Swan, Kratu bounded gleefully around the course, missing jumps, ignoring obstacles and even running over to say hello to a group of volunteers mid-way through.Then he ran into a plastic tunnel and failed to come out the other side, finally emerging from the end he had gone in. Commentator Peter Purvis declared: “I love it. That’s the real trick, to turn around in there. How did he do that ” The joyful display won Kratu, a fluffy Carpathian-Mioritic mix, fans around the world and invites back to Crufts for the next two years.  His  agility performance, his last before retiring, was just as show-stopping, the mischievous Kratu even making off with a pole from one of the hurdles. But while Kratu and Tess’s Crufts appearances never fail to amuse, the story of how they found each other – and rescued each other – is truly heartwarming. Tess, , whose book, Incredible Kratu, was published this week, credits him with helping her recover after she fell into a spiral of addiction and abuse. She says: “He saved my le. I was very tired of le. Some of my memories are horric. I saved Kratu’s le, and he’s saved mine many times. “He’s the reason I get up every morning.”Undiagnosed autistic Tess’s le began to fall apart at the age of  after her father died and she found herself living in a filthy squat in a block of flats in Lambeth, north London. After her boyfriend died of a drugs overdose, Tess turned to heroin as “a respite from the pain”. She says: “I’d tried to take my own le a couple of times. Living was so painful. I was totally used and abused.” Tess, who had a daughter in this time, got deeply involved in London’s criminal world. But contracting hepatitis C was a “wake-up call” and she moved to Cambridgeshire, where she got clean, but still struggled with PTSD. Then a dog rescuer friend, Celia, found a “frightened pup” in a Roma camp in Romania. Tess says: “She told me she knew he was the one for me. I soon fell in love with him, I knew he was going to be my best friend.” But he was a handful – “like having the Honey Monster on a lead” – so she got help from dog trainer Wendy Kruger at Wood Green Animal Shelter in Godmanchester, Cambs. Kratu came on so well she entered him into some agility courses at dog shows. Tess recalls his first, saying: “We were just coming up to the last jump and he turned around and did the entire course backwards, with me chasing him in astonishment. “It was hilarious.”  Tess and Kratu entered Crufts in , when he completed the course without many mishaps. It was on theirthe next year that he stole the show. Tess says: “When he went into that tunnel and didn’t come out the other end, I was like a rabbit in the headlights. It was like, ‘Where the b****y hell has my dog gone ’ “Afterwards I gave him a big hug. I realised what he did was far better, he was a free spirit. That ticked all my boxes. I just embraced him for the rebel and the rascal that he is.  “He makes me laugh so much and that’s one of the biggest gts for me, to laugh, after a letime of crying and pain and sadness and despair. “He knows what sets me off, and now I roar with laughter at him.” Incredible Kratu by Tess Eagle Swan and Lynne Barrett-Lee is available now .
